description: Adobe Photoshop Creative Cloud is a leader in image editing software.  It allows users to manipulate, crop, resize, and correct color on digital photos. Photoshop has become the stand in image manipulation among professional photographers and graphic designers. This course covers exam objectives for the Adobe Certified Associate (ACA) certification.
name: Photoshop CC
subtitle: Photo Editing Application

episodes.title: Exploring the User Interface
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.882 --> 00:00:15.161
Hello, welcome to another
exciting episode here at ITProTV.

3
00:00:15.161 --> 00:00:17.420
I'm your host, Mike Rodrick.

4
00:00:17.420 --> 00:00:19.947
And today we're doing
Adobe Photoshop CC 2015.

5
00:00:19.947 --> 00:00:23.917
And specifically in this episode we're
gonna be taking a look at the user

6
00:00:23.917 --> 00:00:24.640
interface.

7
00:00:24.640 --> 00:00:29.013
An important part of learning any
application, especially one that can be as

8
00:00:29.013 --> 00:00:32.390
complex as this is to learn
your way around that interface.

9
00:00:32.390 --> 00:00:34.420
And here to help us with that is Ms.
Kara Page.

10
00:00:34.420 --> 00:00:35.330
How you doing, Kara?

11
00:00:35.330 --> 00:00:37.070
I'm great, are you ready to get started?

12
00:00:37.070 --> 00:00:37.602
>> I am.

13
00:00:37.602 --> 00:00:43.050
>> All right, so go ahead and
open up Photoshop on your end, okay?

14
00:00:43.050 --> 00:00:45.590
So let's make sure that it's up and
running.

15
00:00:45.590 --> 00:00:48.680
It should look very similar to my screen.

16
00:00:48.680 --> 00:00:53.490
So when you open up CC 2015, it defaults
to this screen where it shows you

17
00:00:53.490 --> 00:00:58.020
recent files, libraries,
presets, and that's

18
00:00:58.020 --> 00:01:01.320
really helpful once you've been using
Photoshop cuz that's where your files are.

19
00:01:01.320 --> 00:01:04.350
So if you wanna pull up a recent
file it's there for you.

20
00:01:04.350 --> 00:01:07.192
If you've never used Photoshop before,
that doesn't help you very much.

21
00:01:07.192 --> 00:01:08.430
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

22
00:01:08.430 --> 00:01:10.147
>> So what we're going to do, just so

23
00:01:10.147 --> 00:01:14.020
you can see the entire workspace, is we
are going to click on this New button.

24
00:01:14.020 --> 00:01:14.690
So it says New...

25
00:01:15.960 --> 00:01:20.540
I'm going to click on it and
it pulls up this Preferences window.

26
00:01:20.540 --> 00:01:23.580
I'm just going to select
document type US Paper.

27
00:01:23.580 --> 00:01:26.550
That's probably what yours
is defaulted to as well.

28
00:01:26.550 --> 00:01:31.611
If it's not, just click on this dropdown
here and select US Paper, okay.

29
00:01:31.611 --> 00:01:34.480
And then go ahead and click OK.

30
00:01:34.480 --> 00:01:37.355
And now we have our workspace
up in it's full glory.

31
00:01:37.355 --> 00:01:38.294
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] So

32
00:01:38.294 --> 00:01:41.246
what we're going to do is we're
gonna take a tour of Photoshop.

33
00:01:41.246 --> 00:01:44.970
So we're not gonna be learning
the tools or the real intricacies.

34
00:01:44.970 --> 00:01:48.680
We're learning a road map
on how to use Photoshop.

35
00:01:48.680 --> 00:01:50.120
So, let's go ahead and get started and

36
00:01:50.120 --> 00:01:54.900
talk about what these top words
are here at the top of your screen.

37
00:01:54.900 --> 00:02:00.140
These are your file options,
your main toolbar here, okay.

38
00:02:00.140 --> 00:02:02.750
So it's your main menu.

39
00:02:02.750 --> 00:02:05.570
If you're on a Mac versus a PC it's
going to look slightly different.

40
00:02:05.570 --> 00:02:09.618
Don't worry, they both have the same
capabilities, just certain tools or

41
00:02:09.618 --> 00:02:12.413
certain options are hidden
under a different menu.

42
00:02:12.413 --> 00:02:15.362
>> Of course,
make it a little more complex for us.

43
00:02:15.362 --> 00:02:18.313
[LAUGH]
>> Yes, yes, so if you're on a Mac you'll

44
00:02:18.313 --> 00:02:23.810
have this Photoshop CC here, with options
like Preferences, Services and things.

45
00:02:23.810 --> 00:02:26.530
This Preferences option,
if you are on a PC,

46
00:02:26.530 --> 00:02:29.230
is actually hidden under your Edit menu.

47
00:02:29.230 --> 00:02:31.970
That's one of the main differences here.

48
00:02:31.970 --> 00:02:34.520
So under this Photoshop CC menu,

49
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:39.540
you can learn about your version of CC,
what updated version you're on.

50
00:02:39.540 --> 00:02:41.905
You can learn about your
plugins if you're interested.

51
00:02:41.905 --> 00:02:46.310
[LAUGH] You can pull up your preferences,
which is really, really helpful.

52
00:02:46.310 --> 00:02:51.190
So your preferences sets everything from
what color you want your screen to be,

53
00:02:51.190 --> 00:02:52.790
to your units and rulers,

54
00:02:52.790 --> 00:02:56.990
whether you want them to be in
something called pixels or inches.

55
00:02:56.990 --> 00:02:58.920
You can set your export options.

56
00:02:58.920 --> 00:03:03.720
It's all available for you here under this
Photoshop CC menu, or Edit Preferences,

57
00:03:03.720 --> 00:03:05.750
depending on where you are.

58
00:03:05.750 --> 00:03:07.810
You can also quit Photoshop
from here as well.

59
00:03:07.810 --> 00:03:09.160
So if you're trying to close it out and

60
00:03:09.160 --> 00:03:13.610
you don't have that X like you do on
a Windows, you can quit it from this menu.

61
00:03:13.610 --> 00:03:17.150
Let's go into File, and I'm gonna go
ahead and zoom into this a little bit, so

62
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:18.510
you can really see this.

63
00:03:19.770 --> 00:03:22.260
So this File menu is pretty helpful for

64
00:03:22.260 --> 00:03:26.590
you cuz this is where you're going to go
when you want to create a new document,

65
00:03:26.590 --> 00:03:31.025
open an existing document, or place
a document into your current document.

66
00:03:31.025 --> 00:03:33.920
So this File > New button right here,

67
00:03:33.920 --> 00:03:36.655
that is what we would do if
we want a blank work space.

68
00:03:36.655 --> 00:03:38.360
It's what we did just a minute ago.

69
00:03:38.360 --> 00:03:40.374
So we have this nice white sheet of paper,

70
00:03:40.374 --> 00:03:43.783
it's like you took it out of your
notebook and put it on your computer.

71
00:03:43.783 --> 00:03:45.607
That's what you do if
you go to File > New.

72
00:03:45.607 --> 00:03:49.930
File > Open is if you
have an existing file.

73
00:03:49.930 --> 00:03:52.870
So let's say that you have a photo
of you on vacation with your family,

74
00:03:52.870 --> 00:03:57.850
you wanna open it up, do some photo edits
to it, you would go to your Open option.

75
00:03:59.330 --> 00:04:02.870
Browse and Bridge, Browse and
Bridge is this cool little way for

76
00:04:02.870 --> 00:04:04.900
you to look at your files.

77
00:04:04.900 --> 00:04:08.430
So Adobe has this program called Bridge,

78
00:04:08.430 --> 00:04:10.680
essentially it's an advanced finder for
you.

79
00:04:10.680 --> 00:04:15.172
So if you are a photographer and
you're taking 200 pictures at a wedding,

80
00:04:15.172 --> 00:04:19.249
you're probably going to want to
browse and bridge as an easier way for

81
00:04:19.249 --> 00:04:22.151
you to find the specific
files you're looking for

82
00:04:22.151 --> 00:04:25.357
instead of seeing a file
name like DC1258376.

83
00:04:25.357 --> 00:04:26.940
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's not really helpful to you.

84
00:04:26.940 --> 00:04:29.420
So Browse and
Bridge might be a good option for you.

85
00:04:29.420 --> 00:04:33.460
You can also open as a Smart Object.

86
00:04:33.460 --> 00:04:37.370
So a Smart Object would be maybe something
that you've created in another program

87
00:04:37.370 --> 00:04:38.420
like Illustrator.

88
00:04:38.420 --> 00:04:43.210
If you want to open up a logo,
you can open it as a Smart Object.

89
00:04:43.210 --> 00:04:44.680
You also have Open Recent.

90
00:04:44.680 --> 00:04:47.010
So if you hover over your Open Recent,

91
00:04:47.010 --> 00:04:51.070
it'll pull up all of the different
files that you have opened.

92
00:04:51.070 --> 00:04:53.480
My most recent was logoexample.psd.

93
00:04:53.480 --> 00:04:57.458
You can also do Close, Close All,
Close and Go To Bridge, so

94
00:04:57.458 --> 00:05:00.900
if you need to get out of something,
you can do that.

95
00:05:00.900 --> 00:05:04.640
You can also hit the little x on
each of your little tab windows.

96
00:05:06.350 --> 00:05:08.410
Your save options are also here.

97
00:05:08.410 --> 00:05:12.590
I highly recommend that you
learn the shortcuts for saving.

98
00:05:12.590 --> 00:05:17.460
So saving in Photoshop on a Mac is Cmd+S,

99
00:05:17.460 --> 00:05:20.490
on a PC, it's Ctrl+S.

100
00:05:20.490 --> 00:05:23.560
When you're in Photoshop, you're going
to want to save, save, save, save,

101
00:05:23.560 --> 00:05:27.220
because you might be doing
a huge document, it's beautiful,

102
00:05:27.220 --> 00:05:31.170
and then all of a sudden, there's
a power outage and you lose everything.

103
00:05:31.170 --> 00:05:35.390
There's nothing more upsetting than losing
work, so make sure to save over and

104
00:05:35.390 --> 00:05:36.180
over and over again.

105
00:05:36.180 --> 00:05:36.862
>> Been there, done that.

106
00:05:36.862 --> 00:05:39.630
>> [LAUGH]
>> And it's so easy just to while you're

107
00:05:39.630 --> 00:05:43.660
working every few minutes Ctrl+S or
Cmd+S, or whichever one you're using.

108
00:05:43.660 --> 00:05:47.800
And it's so easy to do but
people forget to do that.

109
00:05:47.800 --> 00:05:49.790
>> Exactly, so
don't be one of those people.

110
00:05:49.790 --> 00:05:50.486
Learn to save.

111
00:05:50.486 --> 00:05:55.262
So also by clicking this Save As button,
that gives you all of your different file

112
00:05:55.262 --> 00:06:00.050
type options which we'll be going
over in one of our next episodes.

113
00:06:00.050 --> 00:06:02.220
Also under this menu we have Export.

114
00:06:02.220 --> 00:06:05.990
So Export,
you can do a quick export as a pmg.

115
00:06:05.990 --> 00:06:09.180
So pmg is a great file if you
want a transparent background.

116
00:06:09.180 --> 00:06:11.030
It's a smaller file.

117
00:06:11.030 --> 00:06:15.630
There are also other export options here
and export preferences that you can set.

118
00:06:15.630 --> 00:06:19.460
Another important note is if you are doing
anything for web design and you want to

119
00:06:19.460 --> 00:06:26.290
save files specifically for web, under CC
it's now moved to your export file option.

120
00:06:26.290 --> 00:06:30.590
It used to be as its own little thing in
your list right under the Save section.

121
00:06:30.590 --> 00:06:32.030
It said Save for Web.

122
00:06:32.030 --> 00:06:34.000
Now it's under Export,
so keep that in mind.

123
00:06:35.620 --> 00:06:39.430
All right, also on here is something
called Place Embedded and Place Linked.

124
00:06:39.430 --> 00:06:43.960
That is when you want to put another
picture on top of your existing document,

125
00:06:43.960 --> 00:06:44.910
for example.

126
00:06:44.910 --> 00:06:48.090
So let's say that we wanted to take
a picture of your vacation and

127
00:06:48.090 --> 00:06:50.460
put it on on our white blank space here.

128
00:06:50.460 --> 00:06:55.130
It's almost as if we are taking a physical
picture and just placing it on the table.

129
00:06:55.130 --> 00:06:57.900
That's what Place Placing is.

130
00:06:57.900 --> 00:07:00.810
So you have two options,
embedded and linked.

131
00:07:00.810 --> 00:07:04.050
Embedded is your traditional
Photoshop option.

132
00:07:04.050 --> 00:07:06.930
So, if you're on an old version of
Photoshop, it will just say Placed.

133
00:07:06.930 --> 00:07:09.640
It won't say Placed,
Embedded Place Linked.

134
00:07:09.640 --> 00:07:13.470
Place Linked is if you
want to place an item and

135
00:07:13.470 --> 00:07:17.020
be able to link it to all of its
other instances on your computer.

136
00:07:17.020 --> 00:07:20.990
Okay, so if you make an edit you
can make an edit on all instances.

137
00:07:20.990 --> 00:07:24.316
So if you have a logo and you change
the color of your logo and you want it to

138
00:07:24.316 --> 00:07:28.098
change everywhere, having your files
linked would allow you to do that, okay.

139
00:07:30.990 --> 00:07:35.937
Also down here in this bottom part of our
File menu, you see we have Import, Export,

140
00:07:35.937 --> 00:07:38.950
and then we also have your Print options,
as well.

141
00:07:38.950 --> 00:07:41.270
So those are all under your File menu.

142
00:07:43.200 --> 00:07:44.140
Let's go to our next one.

143
00:07:44.140 --> 00:07:46.494
So our next one is our Edit menu.

144
00:07:46.494 --> 00:07:51.456
Editing is where you'd go if you want
to undo, step forward, step backward,

145
00:07:51.456 --> 00:07:55.608
cut, copy, paste, anything like
that is under your Edit menu.

146
00:07:55.608 --> 00:07:59.153
Virtually anything that you do
in Photoshop has a shortcut For

147
00:07:59.153 --> 00:08:02.847
it already and if it doesn't,
you can create a shortcut for it.

148
00:08:02.847 --> 00:08:06.470
So, if you wanna undo something,
don't go up to Edit and Undo.

149
00:08:06.470 --> 00:08:08.200
That just takes too many clicks.

150
00:08:08.200 --> 00:08:11.480
Just do Control Z or Command Z,
so Command if you're on a Mac,

151
00:08:11.480 --> 00:08:12.940
Control if you're on a PC.

152
00:08:14.240 --> 00:08:16.730
You can also cut and paste in Photoshop.

153
00:08:16.730 --> 00:08:20.420
It's the same cut and paste shortcut
options as it is on your computer, so

154
00:08:20.420 --> 00:08:25.220
Command C, Control C, Command V,
Control V, and then you have X for

155
00:08:25.220 --> 00:08:26.810
cutting as well.

156
00:08:26.810 --> 00:08:28.640
Okay, so cut, copy, paste.

157
00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:29.165
Pretty self
>> M-hm.

158
00:08:29.165 --> 00:08:29.885
>> explanatory.

159
00:08:31.180 --> 00:08:34.950
Also under the Edit menu is something that
people don't realize Photoshop has, and

160
00:08:34.950 --> 00:08:37.350
that is a way to check your spelling.

161
00:08:37.350 --> 00:08:38.190
>> Hm.

162
00:08:38.190 --> 00:08:40.980
>> Okay, so this is really, really
important when you're creating a design

163
00:08:40.980 --> 00:08:42.960
for a client and
you love it and it's great.

164
00:08:42.960 --> 00:08:45.320
You've spent hours and hours and
hours and hours working on it.

165
00:08:45.320 --> 00:08:48.555
And then you hand it over to
the client and they see a typo.

166
00:08:48.555 --> 00:08:51.310
>> [LAUGH] That's not gonna be good for
business is it?

167
00:08:51.310 --> 00:08:54.870
>> No, so make sure to check spelling.

168
00:08:54.870 --> 00:08:57.870
And also, just make a habit of
you checking it as well, and

169
00:08:57.870 --> 00:09:01.810
then having Photoshop check because you
don't wanna completely rely on a program

170
00:09:01.810 --> 00:09:06.410
to check your spelling either, especially
if you're spelling out people's names.

171
00:09:06.410 --> 00:09:08.335
Because Photoshop's not going to know.

172
00:09:08.335 --> 00:09:12.080
[LAUGH] You can also find and
replace text.

173
00:09:12.080 --> 00:09:16.740
So let's say that you have a person's
name, and they recently got married, and

174
00:09:16.740 --> 00:09:18.200
you need to change out their last name.

175
00:09:18.200 --> 00:09:22.130
You can find their existing last name,
replace text with their new last name.

176
00:09:22.130 --> 00:09:24.730
>> Nice.
>> Then there's something called Fill and

177
00:09:24.730 --> 00:09:26.440
Stroke under this Edit menu.

178
00:09:26.440 --> 00:09:30.580
So, filling is if you want to
fill something with a color.

179
00:09:30.580 --> 00:09:33.690
So let's say that you have
this white blank document.

180
00:09:33.690 --> 00:09:35.330
You want to fill it with a solid color.

181
00:09:35.330 --> 00:09:38.670
You would go to Edit and Fill.

182
00:09:38.670 --> 00:09:41.590
Okay?
A stroke is if you want to add an outline

183
00:09:41.590 --> 00:09:42.650
to something.

184
00:09:42.650 --> 00:09:47.240
So let's say we wanted to give a border
to a shape we would go to our Stroke

185
00:09:47.240 --> 00:09:49.180
option, okay?

186
00:09:49.180 --> 00:09:52.330
Also under our Edit menu we have
all these Transform controls.

187
00:09:52.330 --> 00:09:55.160
So let me zoom into this so
you can see this a little bit better here.

188
00:09:58.480 --> 00:10:02.920
Okay, so we have Puppet Warp, Perspective
Warp, Free Transform, Transform.

189
00:10:02.920 --> 00:10:06.120
All of these are ways
to manipulate an image.

190
00:10:06.120 --> 00:10:09.229
The first one listed here is Puppet Warp.

191
00:10:09.229 --> 00:10:11.520
Content-Aware Scale's first but

192
00:10:11.520 --> 00:10:16.070
that's more when you're resizing things,
that's where it's gonna come into play.

193
00:10:16.070 --> 00:10:20.060
These other Transform controls are more
when you have, let's say that you place

194
00:10:20.060 --> 00:10:23.710
a picture of a banana or a piece of
an apple in here and you want to change

195
00:10:23.710 --> 00:10:27.030
the way that it looks, these are your
transform controls that you would use.

196
00:10:27.030 --> 00:10:27.990
So Puppet Warp.

197
00:10:27.990 --> 00:10:30.340
Puppet Warp is this fascinating thing.

198
00:10:30.340 --> 00:10:33.270
Let's say that you have a picture
of a model and you like the way

199
00:10:33.270 --> 00:10:36.760
that she's standing but you don't
like where she's placed her hand.

200
00:10:36.760 --> 00:10:42.070
Puppet Warp allows you to set anchor
Points and move where her hand is.

201
00:10:42.070 --> 00:10:44.900
So it's almost like you're taking
one of those marionette puppets and

202
00:10:44.900 --> 00:10:46.160
kind of playing around with it.

203
00:10:46.160 --> 00:10:47.010
>> That's amazing.

204
00:10:47.010 --> 00:10:50.510
>> Yes, perspective warp is
something that you would use if,

205
00:10:50.510 --> 00:10:54.300
let's say that you
are designing something and

206
00:10:54.300 --> 00:10:58.260
you have an existing picture where
it has some kind of dimension to it.

207
00:10:58.260 --> 00:11:01.820
So maybe it's a picture of Times Square,
and you want to change out one of

208
00:11:01.820 --> 00:11:04.780
the buildings to be something
that you've created or

209
00:11:04.780 --> 00:11:07.640
a billboard that has your ad on it or
something.

210
00:11:07.640 --> 00:11:13.230
You can do perspective warp to kind of
change the way your image is seen in

211
00:11:13.230 --> 00:11:13.760
that picture.

212
00:11:14.860 --> 00:11:16.710
Also Free Transform and Transform.

213
00:11:16.710 --> 00:11:22.110
This is what you do if you want to rotate,
scale, flip anything like

214
00:11:22.110 --> 00:11:25.520
that where your changing the direction
of your image is under your Transform.

215
00:11:25.520 --> 00:11:29.280
You can also set presets
under your edit menu as well.

216
00:11:29.280 --> 00:11:33.610
So you can set brush presets,
your Adobe PDF presets,

217
00:11:33.610 --> 00:11:36.969
color settings, keyboard shortcuts,
menus, toolbars.

218
00:11:36.969 --> 00:11:40.960
So edit is where you go if you want to
edit what's already in Photoshop as well

219
00:11:40.960 --> 00:11:42.890
as edit your existing document.

220
00:11:42.890 --> 00:11:47.725
So it's a very long list here, you'll
notice that this drop down is extensive.

221
00:11:47.725 --> 00:11:51.230
[LAUGH] So when in doubt check Edit.

222
00:11:51.230 --> 00:11:54.710
>> Yeah [LAUGH]
>> Then we have our Image menu.

223
00:11:54.710 --> 00:11:57.650
So up here we have Image Mode.

224
00:11:57.650 --> 00:12:04.070
Image Mode are your color modes, so RGB,
CMYK, Lab, all of these are here for you.

225
00:12:04.070 --> 00:12:08.590
You're probably primarily going
to be designing in RGB or CMYK.

226
00:12:08.590 --> 00:12:12.830
So RGB is what you use for
digital screens or digital designs.

227
00:12:12.830 --> 00:12:14.890
CMYK is what you use for print.

228
00:12:16.670 --> 00:12:18.000
Then you have adjustments.

229
00:12:18.000 --> 00:12:21.960
So adjustments are if you want
to do something to your image,

230
00:12:21.960 --> 00:12:26.100
like change the brightness, change
the hue, saturation, doing it from this

231
00:12:26.100 --> 00:12:31.050
menu right here, this is going to to
be destructively editing your photo.

232
00:12:31.050 --> 00:12:32.680
So on the exam,

233
00:12:32.680 --> 00:12:36.570
if you're told to destructively
edit your image by setting a hue or

234
00:12:36.570 --> 00:12:43.080
saturation of 70, you would get to it
by going to Image Adjustments this way.

235
00:12:43.080 --> 00:12:43.810
Okay.
So

236
00:12:43.810 --> 00:12:46.390
destructive means that you're
permanently altering that image.

237
00:12:47.700 --> 00:12:50.490
There are other ways in Photoshop
to do things non-destructively,

238
00:12:50.490 --> 00:12:51.690
which you will learn about.

239
00:12:51.690 --> 00:12:53.581
But just keep in mind, as a little nugget.

240
00:12:53.581 --> 00:12:55.408
>> [Laugh]
>> That when you are on the test,

241
00:12:55.408 --> 00:12:57.530
this is where you would go.

242
00:12:57.530 --> 00:13:01.960
You also have Auto Tone, Auto Contrast,
Auto Color, those are ways for

243
00:13:01.960 --> 00:13:04.980
Photoshop to automatically
correct your image for you.

244
00:13:06.370 --> 00:13:09.440
Then you have Image Size and Canvas Size.

245
00:13:09.440 --> 00:13:14.550
Image Size is the size of your image,
so let's say that this

246
00:13:14.550 --> 00:13:18.760
document right here that we have open,
it's image size would be an 8.5 by 11.

247
00:13:18.760 --> 00:13:23.180
The canvas size would also be 8.5 by
11 because they're one and the same.

248
00:13:23.180 --> 00:13:26.305
Let's say that we wanted to
have a canvas behind our image.

249
00:13:26.305 --> 00:13:27.530
You could add one.

250
00:13:27.530 --> 00:13:32.460
So let's say that we wanted a matte as if
it were a photo to be placed in a frame.

251
00:13:32.460 --> 00:13:34.550
You could do that by adjusting the canvas.

252
00:13:34.550 --> 00:13:39.440
So the canvas is the largest
part of your document.

253
00:13:39.440 --> 00:13:40.060
Okay?

254
00:13:40.060 --> 00:13:43.620
So let's say that we wanted
a canvas to be an inch out

255
00:13:43.620 --> 00:13:47.490
from our existing picture,
our existing blank space.

256
00:13:47.490 --> 00:13:49.029
You can do that under canvas size.

257
00:13:50.610 --> 00:13:53.850
You can also rotate images
under Image as well.

258
00:13:55.060 --> 00:13:59.410
Its very similar to your Edit Transform,
so really either place you wanna go, but

259
00:13:59.410 --> 00:14:02.060
Image Rotation also lets
you adjust your canvas.

260
00:14:03.430 --> 00:14:07.090
You can also duplicate,
apply any kind of image that you've done,

261
00:14:07.090 --> 00:14:10.590
trim your document,
crop it all under Image.

262
00:14:10.590 --> 00:14:11.720
Okay?

263
00:14:11.720 --> 00:14:12.660
Next is your Layer.

264
00:14:12.660 --> 00:14:15.750
So Layer has an entire panel unto itself.

265
00:14:15.750 --> 00:14:17.730
We're going to talk about
panels in just a moment.

266
00:14:17.730 --> 00:14:20.960
So chances are you're never going
to go up to this layer menu,

267
00:14:20.960 --> 00:14:26.060
because there's a much easier way
to look at layers in a panel.

268
00:14:26.060 --> 00:14:30.660
But if you forget how to access the panel
and you panic on the test, don't forget to

269
00:14:30.660 --> 00:14:33.780
check the words along the top of your
screen, cuz it will give you a hint.

270
00:14:33.780 --> 00:14:37.820
So if you need to do anything with layers,
this is where you could go if you

271
00:14:37.820 --> 00:14:40.949
forget how to access your layers panel,
which I'll show you in just a moment.

272
00:14:42.480 --> 00:14:44.440
Then you have your Type menu.

273
00:14:44.440 --> 00:14:47.930
So Type has to do with anything with text.

274
00:14:47.930 --> 00:14:52.960
So if you need to change your font,if
you want to create a character style,

275
00:14:52.960 --> 00:14:56.250
a paragraph style,
that's all under Panels.

276
00:14:56.250 --> 00:14:57.020
So Panels,

277
00:14:57.020 --> 00:15:01.650
what they are are fly out menus that you
can access on your Photoshop screen.

278
00:15:01.650 --> 00:15:05.860
I'll be showing you one of those in
just a moment when we get to Window.

279
00:15:05.860 --> 00:15:11.240
So anything that has to do with text,
you'll find it under your Type menu.

280
00:15:11.240 --> 00:15:13.570
It'll also be in your Panel and

281
00:15:13.570 --> 00:15:17.520
along the top of your screen when
you have your Type Tool selected.

282
00:15:18.770 --> 00:15:21.940
Speaking of selecting there's
an option called Select.

283
00:15:21.940 --> 00:15:25.630
So Select is where'd you go if you
want to do Select All, Deselect,

284
00:15:25.630 --> 00:15:28.000
Reselect, Select Inverse.

285
00:15:28.000 --> 00:15:31.620
So selecting inverse is
selecting the opposite.

286
00:15:31.620 --> 00:15:35.170
So let's say that you have
a white piece of paper, and

287
00:15:35.170 --> 00:15:38.280
you have a pencil in the middle.

288
00:15:38.280 --> 00:15:40.850
You want to select that white document.

289
00:15:40.850 --> 00:15:42.510
What you could do is select your pencil.

290
00:15:42.510 --> 00:15:44.885
Select inverse and
then delete your background.

291
00:15:44.885 --> 00:15:46.470
>> Uh-huh.

292
00:15:46.470 --> 00:15:48.941
>> Okay.
You can also select a color range from

293
00:15:48.941 --> 00:15:50.237
your Select menu too.

294
00:15:50.237 --> 00:15:53.345
So if you're asked on your test,
hey, select a color range.

295
00:15:53.345 --> 00:15:56.523
This is where it's hidden,
under your Select menu.

296
00:15:56.523 --> 00:16:01.842
Key, if it starts with select, maybe you
wanna check your menu, see if it's there.

297
00:16:01.842 --> 00:16:06.705
You can also find masking options here,
which we'll be talking about,

298
00:16:06.705 --> 00:16:10.451
as well as editing in Quick Mask,
loading selections,

299
00:16:10.451 --> 00:16:14.218
saving selections,
it's all under your Select menu.

300
00:16:14.218 --> 00:16:17.310
Our next menu is something called Filter.

301
00:16:17.310 --> 00:16:20.139
So Filter's a really powerful menu.

302
00:16:20.139 --> 00:16:23.879
So it's where you would go if you wanted
to make edits, let's say that you wanted

303
00:16:23.879 --> 00:16:28.590
to make your picture look like it's been
painted, you could go to your Filter menu.

304
00:16:28.590 --> 00:16:33.320
You could also do things like add a blur
to your overall image by going to your

305
00:16:33.320 --> 00:16:34.930
Filter menu as well.

306
00:16:34.930 --> 00:16:39.486
There's a whole filter gallery in here,
where you can actually click through and

307
00:16:39.486 --> 00:16:42.270
see what the filters are going
to do to your image.

308
00:16:42.270 --> 00:16:43.262
>> Nice.

309
00:16:43.262 --> 00:16:44.454
>> Then I have 3D.

310
00:16:44.454 --> 00:16:48.467
So 3D is where you'd wanna go if you
are creating some kind of 3D design in

311
00:16:48.467 --> 00:16:49.810
Photoshop.

312
00:16:49.810 --> 00:16:54.260
Photoshop CC has very powerful 3D tools,
so if 3D design is something that you're

313
00:16:54.260 --> 00:16:58.240
interested in,
this is where you'd find more information.

314
00:16:59.910 --> 00:17:01.950
Then we have our View menu.

315
00:17:01.950 --> 00:17:06.440
So View has everything from zooming in,
zooming out, to setting up proofs for

316
00:17:06.440 --> 00:17:07.710
printing.

317
00:17:07.710 --> 00:17:10.960
It's all the different ways that
you can view your document.

318
00:17:10.960 --> 00:17:14.100
So proof setup is where you would go if,
let's say that you wanted

319
00:17:14.100 --> 00:17:16.970
to see exactly what it would like
when you sent it to a printer.

320
00:17:16.970 --> 00:17:21.800
You would go to Proof Setup, pull up your
proof colors, all of that's there for you.

321
00:17:23.160 --> 00:17:26.370
Zooming in and out,
you can do from this View menu.

322
00:17:26.370 --> 00:17:30.110
But there are so many different ways
to zoom in and out on Photoshop.

323
00:17:30.110 --> 00:17:33.931
I recommend you find a faster way,
so maybe Cmd +,

324
00:17:33.931 --> 00:17:37.952
Cmd Ctrl +, Ctrl- is to zoom in and out.

325
00:17:37.952 --> 00:17:40.460
You can also change
the percentage on your window.

326
00:17:40.460 --> 00:17:42.220
You can do all sorts of different things.

327
00:17:42.220 --> 00:17:46.090
The magnifying tool, just lots and lots of
different options in Photoshop for you.

328
00:17:47.130 --> 00:17:50.480
Also under the View menu,
you have your rulers and guides.

329
00:17:50.480 --> 00:17:52.580
So rulers are what I
have enabled right now.

330
00:17:52.580 --> 00:17:56.330
If you look at the top of my screen,
you'll see these numbers here.

331
00:17:56.330 --> 00:18:00.240
This is a ruler, this is helpful
if you're trying to figure out

332
00:18:00.240 --> 00:18:02.360
exactly where you want
to place something or

333
00:18:02.360 --> 00:18:08.400
how large something should be in relation
to something else, a ruler is helpful.

334
00:18:08.400 --> 00:18:10.633
You also have your guides
under here as well.

335
00:18:10.633 --> 00:18:13.572
So if you wanted to create a guide,
what that is,

336
00:18:13.572 --> 00:18:16.171
is it lets you set
a point on your document.

337
00:18:16.171 --> 00:18:20.995
Let's say that you wanted to find the
midpoint of your document, you can drag it

338
00:18:20.995 --> 00:18:26.190
over from your ruler, set it, and then you
can align all of your objects to it, okay.

339
00:18:27.550 --> 00:18:32.090
So New Guide, Lock Guide, they're
all at the bottom of your View menu.

340
00:18:32.090 --> 00:18:34.304
Then you have this Window, so

341
00:18:34.304 --> 00:18:38.590
Window is where you would go
if you need to find a panel.

342
00:18:38.590 --> 00:18:41.020
So I mentioned panels before,
they're little fly out menus.

343
00:18:41.020 --> 00:18:45.210
If you don't have them up already,
go to Window to enable them.

344
00:18:45.210 --> 00:18:50.030
So this shows you all of your different
panel options, there are a ton of them.

345
00:18:50.030 --> 00:18:53.000
So if you're looking for
Character, Paragraph, Brush,

346
00:18:53.000 --> 00:18:54.910
they're all here under Window.

347
00:18:54.910 --> 00:18:58.770
At the top of Window,
you'll see that you have Window Arrange.

348
00:18:58.770 --> 00:19:02.650
Window Arrange allows you to set
how you want to view your files.

349
00:19:02.650 --> 00:19:05.520
So let's say that you
have four pictures open,

350
00:19:05.520 --> 00:19:08.710
they all show up as little tabs
across the top of your screen.

351
00:19:08.710 --> 00:19:11.090
If you don't want them
to show up like that,

352
00:19:11.090 --> 00:19:14.960
you can say to tile horizontally, four up,

353
00:19:14.960 --> 00:19:19.190
six up, consolidate all to tabs, all
sorts of different things for you there.

354
00:19:19.190 --> 00:19:20.970
This is a designer's preference, so

355
00:19:20.970 --> 00:19:25.400
if you don't like the way that Photoshop's
defaulted, you can change that there.

356
00:19:26.430 --> 00:19:29.160
Also under Window is an option for
Work Space.

357
00:19:29.160 --> 00:19:33.760
So Work Space are all the default
preferences that are already in Photoshop.

358
00:19:33.760 --> 00:19:36.190
You were probably on Essentials Default,
which is fine.

359
00:19:36.190 --> 00:19:37.720
If you're not, you can change to it or

360
00:19:37.720 --> 00:19:41.060
stay in whatever kind of work
space you're in currently.

361
00:19:41.060 --> 00:19:44.060
So let's say that you were
designing motion graphics.

362
00:19:44.060 --> 00:19:49.130
So doing some kind of video editing, you
might want your work space to say Motion.

363
00:19:49.130 --> 00:19:53.920
Or if you're doing work space and you are
a painter, you're an artist, you're doing

364
00:19:53.920 --> 00:19:58.830
a lot of painting in Photoshop,
you can go to Painting here, as well.

365
00:19:58.830 --> 00:20:03.670
Okay, so what that does is it sets what
kind of panels it thinks you need.

366
00:20:03.670 --> 00:20:06.260
You can also set your own work space too.

367
00:20:06.260 --> 00:20:09.440
So if you like your work
space to look a certain way,

368
00:20:09.440 --> 00:20:13.480
kind of like how people organize
their desks, it's a very similar way.

369
00:20:13.480 --> 00:20:17.010
You can pick what tools you want where,
what panels you want where,

370
00:20:17.010 --> 00:20:18.500
what colors you want.

371
00:20:18.500 --> 00:20:19.720
It's all available for you.

372
00:20:19.720 --> 00:20:22.480
Photoshop's an extremely
customizable work space.

373
00:20:23.520 --> 00:20:24.460
Then you have your Help menu.

374
00:20:24.460 --> 00:20:27.450
So this is where you'd go if you
wanted to search for an answer.

375
00:20:27.450 --> 00:20:29.305
And you didn't want to look it up online,

376
00:20:29.305 --> 00:20:32.590
[LAUGH] you can look it up
here under Help and Search.

377
00:20:33.950 --> 00:20:36.460
So that is your main menu in Photoshop.

378
00:20:37.550 --> 00:20:40.260
So any questions so
far with the main menu before we move on?

379
00:20:40.260 --> 00:20:41.700
>> No, a lot of options there.

380
00:20:41.700 --> 00:20:45.220
But I can see we're familiarizing myself
with where things are will make it much

381
00:20:45.220 --> 00:20:47.600
easier to work with
the product in the future.

382
00:20:47.600 --> 00:20:49.870
>> It definitely does, definitely does.

383
00:20:49.870 --> 00:20:53.370
So let me direct your attention to
the far left of the screen now.

384
00:20:53.370 --> 00:20:56.260
Far left over here,
this is your tool panel.

385
00:20:56.260 --> 00:20:58.270
This is where all your tools are located.

386
00:20:58.270 --> 00:20:59.980
So if you're trying to
do something specific,

387
00:20:59.980 --> 00:21:03.270
like use a paintbrush,
this is where you'd go to find it.

388
00:21:03.270 --> 00:21:05.510
Now your tool menu might
look different than mine.

389
00:21:05.510 --> 00:21:07.310
I have mine double stacked.

390
00:21:07.310 --> 00:21:11.250
If you like it like this, you can just
hit these double arrows on the left.

391
00:21:12.290 --> 00:21:16.670
I'm going to collapse mine just so
it's easier for you all to see.

392
00:21:16.670 --> 00:21:21.030
But if you ever see those two arrows, it
just means that you can expand something

393
00:21:21.030 --> 00:21:24.240
or contract it,
depending on what you need to do.

394
00:21:24.240 --> 00:21:28.574
All right, so I'm going to quickly go over
where these tools are and briefly explain

395
00:21:28.574 --> 00:21:32.173
them, but we are going to be going
over each of these tools in depth, so

396
00:21:32.173 --> 00:21:33.296
don't worry there.

397
00:21:33.296 --> 00:21:37.670
[COUGH] All right,
let's go over this first tool.

398
00:21:37.670 --> 00:21:39.910
So this first tool is your Move Tool.

399
00:21:39.910 --> 00:21:41.670
It might look slightly
different on your end.

400
00:21:41.670 --> 00:21:44.100
It will have an arrow
attached to it in some way.

401
00:21:44.100 --> 00:21:46.815
Photoshop keeps changing what the move
tool looks like for some reason.

402
00:21:46.815 --> 00:21:48.999
It's changed twice in the last six months.

403
00:21:48.999 --> 00:21:50.157
I don't know why.

404
00:21:50.157 --> 00:21:50.937
>> Really?

405
00:21:50.937 --> 00:21:52.085
>> Yes, but it has changed.

406
00:21:52.085 --> 00:21:55.230
[LAUGH] Move Tool allows you to
move something on your document.

407
00:21:55.230 --> 00:21:59.360
Then you have your Artboard Tool,
which is a new thing in Photoshop CC.

408
00:21:59.360 --> 00:22:02.660
Artboards are something that's
used in programs like Illustrator,

409
00:22:02.660 --> 00:22:07.550
where you want to have multiple
documents available in one file.

410
00:22:07.550 --> 00:22:09.350
Photoshop didn't used to
allow you to do that.

411
00:22:09.350 --> 00:22:10.070
Now it does.

412
00:22:10.070 --> 00:22:13.440
That is your Artboard Tool, okay?

413
00:22:13.440 --> 00:22:16.910
Going to the immediate right,
these are your Marquee Tools.

414
00:22:16.910 --> 00:22:19.420
Marquee Tools are selection tools.

415
00:22:19.420 --> 00:22:23.150
So if you wanted to select a very
particular part of an image,

416
00:22:23.150 --> 00:22:24.010
you could do that here.

417
00:22:24.010 --> 00:22:26.510
So if you wanted to select
a button off of a shirt,

418
00:22:26.510 --> 00:22:28.920
you could use the Elliptical Marquee Tool.

419
00:22:28.920 --> 00:22:31.530
You could copy it, you could edit it,
you could do whatever you want.

420
00:22:31.530 --> 00:22:34.850
It's just a way to select.

421
00:22:34.850 --> 00:22:38.170
Another way to select is
with the Lasso Tools.

422
00:22:38.170 --> 00:22:42.290
So you have your regular lasso,
polygonal, and then magnetic lasso.

423
00:22:42.290 --> 00:22:45.270
These are ways for you to be more
specific with your selections.

424
00:22:45.270 --> 00:22:46.680
So you can actually click, hold,

425
00:22:46.680 --> 00:22:50.400
drag around, get something more
specific than just a geometric shape.

426
00:22:52.350 --> 00:22:56.196
To the right of that, we have another way
to select as your Quick Selection Tool and

427
00:22:56.196 --> 00:22:56.829
Magic Wand.

428
00:22:56.829 --> 00:23:01.729
The Quick Selection Tool allows you
to drag a brush over an image and

429
00:23:01.729 --> 00:23:05.258
select specific parts that you want.

430
00:23:05.258 --> 00:23:09.108
The Magic Wand Tool works in a similar
way, it picks up similar colors, so

431
00:23:09.108 --> 00:23:12.461
that way, you can kind of quickly
remove a white background, or

432
00:23:12.461 --> 00:23:15.404
you can select similar parts
of an image based on color.

433
00:23:15.404 --> 00:23:18.740
To the left, we have our Crop Tool.

434
00:23:18.740 --> 00:23:23.140
So the Crop Tool is a way to
destructively change your image.

435
00:23:23.140 --> 00:23:26.730
So it's like taking a pair of scissors and
cutting off the bottom of a picture.

436
00:23:26.730 --> 00:23:28.980
That's what a Crop Tool does.

437
00:23:28.980 --> 00:23:32.370
So you have Crop,
Perspective Crop and then slicing.

438
00:23:32.370 --> 00:23:37.170
Slicing is something that you do if
you want to create images for the web.

439
00:23:37.170 --> 00:23:40.579
So if you wanted to design
some buttons in Photoshop,

440
00:23:40.579 --> 00:23:42.941
you can slice them out for use on web.

441
00:23:42.941 --> 00:23:46.134
Okay, to the right of that tool, we have
the Eyedropper Tool, the Ruler Tool,

442
00:23:46.134 --> 00:23:48.400
the Note Tool, the Count Tool.

443
00:23:48.400 --> 00:23:51.418
These are ways for
you to organize your document.

444
00:23:51.418 --> 00:23:52.621
Okay, so using notes, so

445
00:23:52.621 --> 00:23:56.465
notes would be something that you'd use if
you wanted to leave a note for yourself.

446
00:23:56.465 --> 00:24:00.428
If you're leaving for the day at work and
You wanna remember where you left off,

447
00:24:00.428 --> 00:24:02.690
you can leave yourself
a little sticky note.

448
00:24:02.690 --> 00:24:03.689
>> Handy.
[LAUGH]

449
00:24:03.689 --> 00:24:04.455
>> Yes.

450
00:24:04.455 --> 00:24:08.240
But what you're probably going to be using
the most from here is the eyedropper tool.

451
00:24:08.240 --> 00:24:12.840
The eyedropper tool allows
you to select colors, okay?

452
00:24:12.840 --> 00:24:15.580
Then, to the far left,
we have our healing brush tools.

453
00:24:15.580 --> 00:24:19.820
This is where you would go if you wanted
to remove a blemish off of a face,

454
00:24:19.820 --> 00:24:23.410
if you wanted to move
something out of a picture.

455
00:24:23.410 --> 00:24:24.490
You can do that here.

456
00:24:26.980 --> 00:24:28.540
Then we have our brush tool.

457
00:24:28.540 --> 00:24:30.900
So, the brush tool has your brush tools,
your pencil tools,

458
00:24:30.900 --> 00:24:32.970
your color replacement tools,
your mixer brushes.

459
00:24:32.970 --> 00:24:34.960
They are all here for you.

460
00:24:34.960 --> 00:24:39.930
This is what you think of when you
remember playing with Paint as a kid,

461
00:24:39.930 --> 00:24:41.480
on Windows maybe.

462
00:24:41.480 --> 00:24:44.380
This is very similar to that,
but it has a lot more options.

463
00:24:44.380 --> 00:24:48.190
You can create really beautiful artistic
designs with your brush tool in Photoshop.

464
00:24:49.580 --> 00:24:52.370
Then you have your clone stamp tool or
pattern stamp tool.

465
00:24:52.370 --> 00:24:56.870
That allows you to copy certain parts of
an image and paste it over another part.

466
00:24:59.200 --> 00:25:01.210
Then you have your history brush tool,
art history brush tool.

467
00:25:01.210 --> 00:25:04.420
These are something that you
probably wouldn't use all that much,

468
00:25:04.420 --> 00:25:07.340
but if for some reason you're ever
asked to do it, here they are.

469
00:25:07.340 --> 00:25:09.930
We're going to be demonstrating
what they do later on.

470
00:25:11.760 --> 00:25:13.390
Then you have your eraser tool.

471
00:25:13.390 --> 00:25:17.270
So, the eraser tool allows you to
destructively remove parts of an image.

472
00:25:17.270 --> 00:25:21.650
So, if you wanted to remove
a line that you'd drawn,

473
00:25:21.650 --> 00:25:23.260
you could use your eraser tool for it.

474
00:25:25.020 --> 00:25:28.660
Then you have your paint bucket tool and
gradient tools.

475
00:25:28.660 --> 00:25:34.620
The gradient tool allows you to create
a fading effect on an image, okay?

476
00:25:34.620 --> 00:25:37.241
The paint bucket tool allows
you to fill an area with color.

477
00:25:39.764 --> 00:25:42.740
Okay?
Then, here you have your blur, sharpen and

478
00:25:42.740 --> 00:25:43.290
smudge tools.

479
00:25:43.290 --> 00:25:47.330
These are a way to edit photos if you
wanted to blur something out, smudge it,

480
00:25:47.330 --> 00:25:49.240
if you wanted to sharpen something so

481
00:25:49.240 --> 00:25:51.690
you could read it better,
this is where you would go.

482
00:25:52.760 --> 00:25:56.640
Similar to those tools is you have
the dodge, burn and sponge tools.

483
00:25:56.640 --> 00:26:00.460
These either brighten parts of an image,
darken parts of an image, or

484
00:26:00.460 --> 00:26:02.620
add saturation to an image.

485
00:26:02.620 --> 00:26:04.850
Like I said, we are going to
be practicing all of these.

486
00:26:04.850 --> 00:26:06.860
This is probably going way over your head.

487
00:26:06.860 --> 00:26:09.950
Just try to remember where they are,
that's the key point here.

488
00:26:09.950 --> 00:26:12.130
Then you have your pen tool.

489
00:26:12.130 --> 00:26:17.040
The pen tool allows you to create
very specific selections, or

490
00:26:17.040 --> 00:26:18.320
to draw something out.

491
00:26:19.410 --> 00:26:23.540
The pen tool is pretty much
the fundamental basis of Illustrator.

492
00:26:23.540 --> 00:26:26.820
So, if you're familiar with Illustrator,
this is very similar.

493
00:26:28.580 --> 00:26:31.020
Then you have your T or your type tool.

494
00:26:31.020 --> 00:26:33.610
This is where you would go
if you wanted to add text.

495
00:26:33.610 --> 00:26:35.370
So you can add horizontal text,

496
00:26:35.370 --> 00:26:37.850
you can add vertical text,
you can do masking text.

497
00:26:37.850 --> 00:26:39.407
It's all there for you.

498
00:26:40.936 --> 00:26:42.520
Then you have your arrow tools.

499
00:26:42.520 --> 00:26:45.090
These are ways for you to select paths.

500
00:26:45.090 --> 00:26:47.449
So if you've created
a path with the pen tool,

501
00:26:47.449 --> 00:26:50.789
this is where you would go to move
those paths or edit those paths.

502
00:26:52.500 --> 00:26:53.590
Then you have your shape tool.

503
00:26:53.590 --> 00:26:57.806
The shape tool allows you to create shapes
like circles, and squares, and lines, and

504
00:26:57.806 --> 00:26:58.629
custom shapes.

505
00:27:00.663 --> 00:27:04.720
The hand tool down here,
it allows you to pan across your document.

506
00:27:04.720 --> 00:27:07.690
So if you have a huge image, let's say
it's a picture of the Grand Canyon,

507
00:27:07.690 --> 00:27:12.490
it's massive, that you took on your
digital camera, you want to zoom in and

508
00:27:12.490 --> 00:27:15.940
move so you can see this
particular animal on the ridge.

509
00:27:15.940 --> 00:27:17.521
You could do that with your hand tool.

510
00:27:19.056 --> 00:27:23.368
Then you have your little magnifying
glass which allows you to zoom, okay?

511
00:27:23.368 --> 00:27:26.550
So, there is a tool for it,
you can also use a shortcut for it.

512
00:27:26.550 --> 00:27:28.350
It's all there for you.

513
00:27:28.350 --> 00:27:31.220
At the bottom of your panel,
these are your colors here,

514
00:27:31.220 --> 00:27:33.640
it's your foreground and
background colors.

515
00:27:33.640 --> 00:27:38.020
So if you're trying to figure out where
to change the color, there you go.

516
00:27:38.020 --> 00:27:43.190
Now there's one more thing I wanted to
show you before we end today's lesson, and

517
00:27:43.190 --> 00:27:44.630
that's where your panels are.

518
00:27:44.630 --> 00:27:47.320
So I've mentioned what panels are,
let's look at them.

519
00:27:47.320 --> 00:27:51.170
So over on the far right is
where you have your panels.

520
00:27:51.170 --> 00:27:53.380
So if you were to click on Layers,

521
00:27:53.380 --> 00:27:56.950
you'd see that you have a little fly
out menu that gives you more options.

522
00:27:56.950 --> 00:28:01.420
So if you needed to create a new layer,
adjust a layer, this is where you'd go.

523
00:28:02.690 --> 00:28:07.480
If we click on color, you'll see how
you can select color, change color.

524
00:28:07.480 --> 00:28:08.850
If you click on swatches,

525
00:28:08.850 --> 00:28:13.220
this is where you'd go to find colors
that are already in Photoshop.

526
00:28:13.220 --> 00:28:15.130
You can also create your own color swatch.

527
00:28:15.130 --> 00:28:17.540
So let's say that you
are creating work for

528
00:28:17.540 --> 00:28:20.770
an existing brand and
they have a particular color swatch.

529
00:28:20.770 --> 00:28:24.150
You can add that swatch to your
Photoshop swatches panel so

530
00:28:24.150 --> 00:28:27.915
that way you have access to that exact
same color whenever you're doing design.

531
00:28:27.915 --> 00:28:33.190
So, again, if you're ever missing
a panel or you want to add a panel,

532
00:28:33.190 --> 00:28:37.930
what you do is you go to window and panels
and you can select whatever one you want.

533
00:28:37.930 --> 00:28:44.310
So let's try, I'll just add,
let's do styles.

534
00:28:45.460 --> 00:28:47.713
So styles, you can either drag it out.

535
00:28:48.875 --> 00:28:51.530
You can expand it, collapse it.

536
00:28:51.530 --> 00:28:52.800
You can pull it back in.

537
00:28:52.800 --> 00:28:57.970
Photoshop is extremely flexible in how
you want it to arrange your workspace.

538
00:28:57.970 --> 00:29:01.930
And that is an introduction
to our Photoshop workspace.

539
00:29:01.930 --> 00:29:03.080
>> Fantastic, Cara.

540
00:29:03.080 --> 00:29:04.490
Great tour of the interface.

541
00:29:04.490 --> 00:29:07.520
Like we said at the very beginning,
a relatively complex application,

542
00:29:07.520 --> 00:29:10.770
important that we can find our way around,
find the tools we need,

543
00:29:10.770 --> 00:29:14.530
know what menus options are under so
that we can work effectively.

544
00:29:14.530 --> 00:29:17.750
And as Cara pointed out several times,
wanna be able to pass that exam as well.

545
00:29:17.750 --> 00:29:19.490
So we thank you for that tour, Cara.

546
00:29:19.490 --> 00:29:22.230
Can't wait to dive in and
learn more about Photoshop.

547
00:29:22.230 --> 00:29:24.260
But that's gonna have to
wait til our next episode.

548
00:29:24.260 --> 00:29:26.790
Signing off for IT Pro TV,
I'm Mike Roderick.

549
00:29:26.790 --> 00:29:27.420
>> And I'm Cara Page.

550
00:29:27.420 --> 00:29:29.638
>> And we'll see you next time.

551
00:29:29.638 --> 00:29:37.370
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: Try It Out! Working with Files
Try It Out! Layer Styles and Shapes
Try It Out! Colors and Filters
Try It Out Image! Correction Tools
